description: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD)is a developmental disorder characterized by impairments in the development of language, communication, and reciprocal interaction and the presence of repetitive and ritualistic behaviors.(1) Onset is before the age of 3 years.(2,30)As of May 2013, the diagnostic label of ASD applies to individuals with characteristics of several conditions that were previously considered separate disorders, including autistic disorder, pervasive developmental disorder not otherwise specified (PDD-NOS),  early infantile autism, atypical autism, Kanner’s autism, high-functioning autism, childhood disintegrative disorder, and Asperger’s syndrome (AS).(30) According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5) , individuals who would have met the diagnostic criteria for any of the aforementioned conditions are now diagnosed with ASD.(30) For detailed information on diagnostic criteria for ASD, see the Clinical Reviews on this topic and the DSM-5 .Specific feeding difficulties associated with ASD are described below

presentation signs and symptoms: Feeding difficulties associated with ASD include strong food preferences, restriction of diet to a narrow range of foods, unusual eating behaviors (e.g., eating inedible items), oral motor difficulties, and refusing to eat certain types of food or entire food groups.(3) In addition to a behavioral component, physiological issues such as sensory processing and gastrointestinal problems might play a role in the feeding skills of patients with ASD(3)
For detailed information on dysphagia in childhood, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia in Childhood ; Topic ID Number: T708938 Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Assessment should include observation of the mealtime routine and interactions between the caregiver and child

causes: The causes of feeding difficulties in individuals with ASD are usually multifactorial and can have physiological,psychopathological, environmental, and behavioral origins.(1,3) Sensory processing issues can lead to restrictive foodpreferences as well as a higher sensitivity to the feeding environment.(3) Many individuals with ASD have gastrointestinalreflux disease (GERD) and may refuse foods that exacerbate the symptoms of GERD. In addition, undesirable behaviorsmay result when a person with ASD cannot communicate discomfort associated with GERD or with other sensorydisturbances related to food.(3) Other characteristics associated with ASD that may influence eating include poor executivefunctioning, lack of mental flexibility (perseverative and idiosyncratic behaviors), intellectual disability, fear and anxiety,and poor social and language skills(3)
pathogenesis: The development of feeding disorders varies in origin and severity with the individual. There is evidence thatenvironmental factors (e.g., distractions from siblings at the table) can influence and exacerbate symptoms in some cases(4)

overall contraindications precautions: ASD is usually diagnosed in very young children; therefore, precautions to evaluation will also be determined by the patient’s age and family concerns. Persons who are very young or who present with speech/language or cognitive impairments may not be able to answer questions regarding medical history. It is recommended that parents and/or caregivers be involved in all assessment procedures

Eating and dietary practices vary considerably across families and cultures. It is important for the speech-language pathologist (SLP) to understand the family’s concerns and objectives regarding feeding and swallowing while assessing specific food types and textures (e.g., if the family is vegetarian, do not assess the patient with non-vegetarian  items)(7)

contraindications precautions to examina: Assessment should include observation of the mealtime routine and interactions between the caregiver and child

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document when ASD was diagnosed, by whom, and when feeding difficulties were first noted

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management will vary according to the patient’s presenting symptoms
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they beingSSRIs are antidepressants that are also used to treat obsessivecompulsive  behaviors and anxiety(6)Tricyclics are antidepressants that are also used to treat obsessive-compulsive behaviors(6)These drugs are used to reduce stereotyped behaviors, decrease hyperactivity, and minimize withdrawal and aggression(6)Stimulants may be used to decrease hyperactivity in individuals with ASD(6)Antianxiety drugs can help to reduce anxiousness and panic disorders associated with ASD(6)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
A functional behavior analysis may be warranted
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack), organic or other types of special diets, or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had behavioral, occupational, physical, or speech therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors -Does the patient have hearing or vision difficulties? -How severe are the patient’s communication difficulties? -Does the patient have a co-occurring  disorder associated with ASD, such as an intellectual disability, epilepsy, or tuberous sclerosis (a disorder that includes seizures resulting from cuts in the brain)?(6) -Does the patient or caregiver/family speak another language at home? -What modality does the patient use to communicate? -Does the patient have GERD or other GI symptoms (e.g., vomiting, diarrhea, chronic loose stools, colon and GI cramping, constipation)?(8) -Is the patient overweight or underweight? -Does the patient have any specific food aversions or aversion towards eating? -Does the patient exhibit any self-injurious behavior? -Is the patient currently taking medication that affects eating or sleeping habits? -Is the caregiver/family aware of the patient’s feeding difficulties? -What are meals like in the home and/or school? -Is the eating environment calming or distracting?(9) -Does the caregiver/family have a special diet or selective food preferences? -What expectations does the caregiver/family have for the patient at mealtimes? -Does the child exhibit behavior difficulties during mealtimes? -How does the caregiver/family respond to the child’s feeding difficulties? -Is there stress associated with mealtimes?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Feeding difficulties in individuals with ASD can have a behavioral, neurological, or psychological basis. Behaviors at mealtimes can resemble behavioral noncompliance but are more likely to be related to ASDFood preferences are typically based upon texture, smell, appearance, and flavor; however, fear and anxiety may also result in avoidance of certain types of food.(3) For example, neophobia, or the fear of any new experience or thing, can result in fear of unknown foods and is common in individuals with ASD.(8) Selective eating can result in poor nutrition and underweight(8)Sensory processing issues can lead to restrictive food preferences (e.g., refusal to eat foods with specific tastes, smells, textures, or colors) as well as a higher sensitivity to the feeding  environment. For example, a school cafeteria setting with fluorescent lights, elevated noise levels, and a variety of smells can overwhelm and agitate a child with ASD, who might be unable to filter out these environmental distractions.(3,11,33) For detailed information about sensory processing disorder, see Clinical Review…SensoryPediatrics ; Topic ID NumberIt is unclear whether there is a higher prevalence of GI issues such as GERD, constipation, diarrhea, and food allergies in children with ASD.(3) Factors associated with ASD such as communication problems may exacerbate the effects of GI issues, resulting in behavior-based  or nonverbal refusal of foods that may potentially cause discomfort(3)Repetitive and ritualistic behaviors are diagnostic features of ASD and may include insistence on specific methods of food preparation, food types, and specific mealtime rules.(3) In addition, executive function difficulties such as impaired planning might result in an individual insisting on eating the same food at each meal to better control and anticipate the mealtime experience(3)Difficulty in self-monitoring  may cause the patient to believe that a meal is finished prematurely. Some individuals with ASD have been noted to disregard internal cues of hunger and rely more on external stimuli such as the time or presence food.(3) Overeating or under-eating  may also be influenced by medications(8)Comprehension issues and communication difficulties can lead to misunderstandings and fear about situations involving food and the food itself. For example, if parents insist on the child engaging in conversation during a meal, the child can develop negative associations with eating associated with these social demands.(3) Communication issues might also prevent the child from indicating food preferences, satiation, hunger, or discomfort associated with eating(10)Disruptive behaviors that interfere with eating may include crying, screaming, aggressive behavior, or self-injurious  behavior(10)Rumination refers to the repetitive regurgitation of recently ingested food into the mouth and has been reported in individuals with intellectual disabilities and ASD. One side effect of rumination is the erosion of the teeth by gastric acid(8)Pica is the eating of inedible, nonfood substances and has been reported in individuals with ASD(8,11,33)Polydipsia refers to dangerous water intoxication and is rare but has been reported in a few individuals with ASD and intellectual disabilities(8)

history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., or eating environment)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Individuals with ASD may have disrupted sleep schedules due to effects of medications
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician or social worker (e.g., depression, anxiety)

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient or caregiver/family about other problems, including communication problems, intellectual disability, epilepsy, and hearing loss

relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document use of any adaptive devices for communication, feeding, or body positioning –For detailed information on communication devices for children with ASD, see Clinical Review…Augmentative andChildren with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) ; Topic ID Number
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisThe SLP may collaborate with a behavior psychologist to assess mealtime behaviors. The SLP’s role is to identify any communication issues regarding feeding/eating and to ensure that the patient is not at risk for dysphagia. When qualified, the SLP may also assess behaviors associated with eating (e.g., functional behavior analysis). Assessment of consistency in feeding can be determined by an interview with the family and multiple mealtime observations. Observations should occur in different settings (e.g., home, cafeteria) and across different meal types (e.g., breakfast, lunch). The SLP may observe feeding in response to different textures and flavor changes as well as other mealtime variables (e.g., type of utensils, noise in the environment).(3) Some examples of standardized measures to assessA caregiver-rated  measure of eating and mealtime problems. Contains questions regarding presence of choking, ability to use cutlery, and parent attitudes associated with the child’s eating behavior(12)A parent-report  measure to assess variation in eating style among children. Some areas that are assessed include responsiveness to food, enjoyment of food, indication of satiety, pace of eating, fussiness, emotional under-eating  or overeating, and desire for drinks(13) A 23-item caregiver report to assess feeding difficulties in patients with mental retardation(14)A 35-item  caregiver report designed to assess mealtime behaviors of children between the ages of 9 months and 8 years(15)An 18-item caregiver report designed to measure mealtime behaviors as well as food preferences of children with ASD(10)Sensory-based  factors might affect the individual’s ability to eat in social settings. A formalized assessment of sensory processing by an OT may be performed(3)Environmental variables such as positive (e.g., earning a desired toy, hearing verbal praise) and negative reinforcement (e.g., using a “No” picture to communicate an undesired food item) have been found to play a role in shaping and maintaining inappropriate mealtime behaviors.(4)Functional analysis can be performed by a trained professional to determine any environmental consequences that contribute to the child’s feeding difficulties (e.g., noise level, visual distractors). The results of this analysis can be used to develop a very specific behavioral treatment plan

other: Eating and dietary practices vary considerably across families and cultures. It is important for the SLP to understand the family’s and patient’s concerns and objectives regarding feeding and swallowing before finalizing any recommendations regarding specific food types and textures(7)

Reduced social contact and social isolation are risks associated with inefficient and restricted eating habits of children and adults with ASD. For example, children who are unable to eat solids might not be able to eat with their peers in the school cafeteria.(16)The SLP should be aware of these potential limitations, and goals for eating should address social integration during mealtimes
High levels of parental distress are associated with young children who have feeding disorders, and clinical/counseling/ support services for families are often warranted(17)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The patient exhibits swallowing impairments or feeding behaviors that negatively affect nutrition and/or the feeding experience(3,11)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Distinguish between organic feeding difficulties (e.g., GERD, allergies, specific food intolerance) and feeding difficulties due to food preferences or environment if possible.(18)Collaborate with the nutritionist or physician to identify any feeding difficulties that are influenced by medication(s)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to a psychologist or behavior specialist might be warranted to assist with behavioral therapy. Refer to a nutritionist if food preferences and mealtime aversions interfere with nutritional intake. Refer to a physician if food allergies or specific food intolerances are suspected. Refer to an OT for a sensory processing assessment and/or assistance with any adaptive eating utensils(3)
treatment summary: Behavioral treatment techniques: Behavioral treatment has been used to address a variety of eating difficulties associated with ASD, including food selectivity and food refusal, lack of compliance, insufficient food consumption, rapid eating, and food packing (packing mouth with food instead of swallowing/pocketing food).(1,34) Behavioral treatment has shown promise with individuals with ASD in case studies and single subject design studies. The following are some examples of behavioral treatment in studies with individuals with feeding disorders: –High-probability  tasks interspersed with low-probability tasks (behavioral momentum): In a high-probability (high-p) instructional sequence, an instruction with low probability of compliance (low-p)  is preceded by an instruction with a high probability of compliance (high-p).  The purpose of the use of this sequence is to increase the occurrence of low-p tasks. The effect of a high-p  instructional sequence on food acceptance and inappropriate behavior of 3 children (ages 2 years, 2 years, and 6 years) was examined in a single subject (reversal design) study in the United States.(22) All 3 children demonstrated some type of food refusal, but none was diagnosed with ASD. Each child was presented with a high-p  task (accepting a nuk brush without food) prior to the presentation of a low-p task (accepting a nuk brush with food). The high-p  sequence consistently increased the acceptance of food by all 3 children. Other studies on high-p sequence have shown contrasting findings with transient or no increases in food acceptance(23,24) –Prompting: Children with ASD have been reported to eat too rapidly, risking choking and hindering adequate digestion. In a United States single subject (reversal design) study, 3 teenagers with ASD who were observed to eat too quickly were taught to take a bite of food only when a pager vibrated at predetermined intervals during meals at school.(25) The vibrating pager increased the total duration of meals and slowed the consumption rate of all 3 teenagers –Fading: The object of a fading procedure is to introduce a previously avoided stimulus in such a way that negative behaviors are not provoked. The stimulus is introduced with a preferred stimulus, and the preferred stimulus is gradually faded as the nonpreferred stimulus is accepted. Children with ASD are often reported to have a limited diet with unhealthy foods.(11) In order to introduce new foods into the individual’s diet, the therapist must proceed slowly.(11) In a case study of a 4-year-old girl with ASD, the objective was to increase the quantity of milk accepted during mealtimes.(26) The subject would not accept any more than a mixture of 50% milk with 50% PediaSure (a supplemental nutritional beverage). During the treatment protocol (30 sessions during meals), the proportion of milk was gradually increased by 6.25% (one tablespoon) across successive sessions. After the treatment sessions (data probe, session 37), the child drank 100% milk –Differential reinforcement of alternative behavior, escape extinction, and demand fading: Reinforcement for eating increasing quantities of previously nonpreferred food has been employed in several studies of children with ASD and feeding disorders.(1) Differential reinforcement refers to positive reinforcement of the desired behavior (e.g., eating a variety of foods) coupled with removal of reinforcement for the undesired behavior (e.g., eating only select foods). Escape extinction refers to the elimination of escape behavior (demand avoidance). One example of an escape behavior would be crying or vomiting when presented with a nonpreferred food item. A multiple baseline across settings design evaluated the effects of differential reinforcement of alternative behavior (DRA), escape extinction, and demand feeding on increasing the variety of accepted food for a 4-year-old  boy with ASD who had a selective diet of candy, chips, and chicken nuggets.(27) DRA treatment sessions were conducted at home by his mother. Initial sessions were terminated when the child accepted a bite of nonpreferred food (e.g., broccoli, cheese, cooked chicken) or when 30 minutes had elapsed. He was allowed to have a plate with four preferred foods when he accepted one bite of nonpreferred food. Bites expelled or vomited resulted in new presentations of the nonpreferred food. When the subject swallowed the required number of bites for three consecutive dinners, the number of bites of nonpreferred foods required for reinforcement was increased. Gradually, the number of bites of the nonpreferred foods increased as the number of bites of the preferred food decreased  –Simultaneous presentation and sequential presentation of foods: Several studies have examined the effectiveness of simultaneous and sequential food presentation in introducing new, previously nonpreferred foods to children with ASD who are selective eaters.(1,28) In a study in the United States of 3 children with ASD, researchers explored the effects of simultaneous vs. sequential presentation of nonpreferred foods.(29) In the simultaneous condition, nonpreferred foods were embedded in preferred foods (e.g., broccoli embedded in an apple), whereas sequential presentation involved following a nonpreferred food with a preferred food. One of the subjects was a 10-year-old  boy with ASD who only ate crunchy foods. The subject made faster initial gains with the simultaneous condition but eventually ate 100% of nonpreferred foods in both conditions –Multicomponent behavioral treatment: In a case study with two 4-year-old  children with ASD, researchers successfully reduced food packing in both children using a multicomponent behavior treatment plan. For each child, a different combination of behavioral techniques was combined to successfully reduce food packing.(34) The following techniques were utilized: -Re-distribution:  removing packed food from the child’s mouth and placing it on the child’s tongue(34) -Nonremoval of the spoon: keeping the spoon in the child’s mouth to prevent packing(34) -Swallow facilitation: stimulating the tongue with a flipped spoon or nuk brush to facilitate swallowing(34) -Chaser treatments: following solid boluses with a liquid wash (or a solid bolus with high rates of acceptance) to reduce packing in the oral cavity(34)

Sensory-based  techniques: Sensory-based  strategies are often recommended by an OT or SLP to address certain behavioral responses (e.g., decreasing self-stimulatory  behavior, improving attention, regulating activity). Specific strategies may include a variety of oral and facial massage techniques as well as introduction of different tastes, temperatures, and textures of food and use of equipment such as straws and chewy tubes. Generalizations regarding the use of sensory-based strategies with children with ASD and feeding difficulties cannot be made due to the absence of empirical evidence.(3) Clinical judgment should be used when implementing sensory-based  techniques, and collaboration with an OT might be indicated. For detailed information on sensory-based therapy techniques, see Clinical Review…Sensory Integration Therapy: Occupational Therapy ; Topic ID Number: T901897 .
